bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to L. H. Baekeland, May 10, 1924 [Enclosed in KAMD0730]

div1.p: Kean's letter to the editor was written in response to an appeal by Emily Lawrence Reed to protect her husband's reputation. More importantly, Kean desires to induce Congress to make a more liberal pension for Reed. Kean does not want Baekeland's letter to distract the public's attention from Walter Reed. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to L. H. Baekeland, May 10, 1924 [Enclosed in KAMD0730]
div1.opener:
JRK-mrh
10 May 1924.
Dr. L. H. Baekeland,
American Chemical Society,
247 Park Avenue,
New York, N. Y.
My dear Dr. Baekeland;
div1.p:
Our friend, Dr. L. O. Howard, has sent me a
copy of the letter which you suggested writing to the New York
Times, in which you very kindly call attention to the fact that I
initiated the sanitary war against mosquitoes in Cuba.

I appreciate, very much, your good will in
this matter, but I would regret very much to have my name brought
forward as a part claimant for credit for the sanitary work in
Cuba, for the following reason:

The letter to the Times was written in response
to an appeal from Major Reed's widow to protect his reputation from
claims of others for the credit which belonged to him. The Surgeon
General also requested me to do something in the matter. While I
regretted extremely to adopt an attitude of criticism of the claims
for her husband of the widow of my old friend, General Gorgas, it
seemed to be necessary to do what I could to resist the prevailing
tendency to forget Reed's splendid work. This is more important,
as I hope some day Congress may be induced to make a more liberal
provision in the way of a pension for Mrs. Reed, than at present, for
Reed's untimely death left her practically without resources, and
the sum of one hundred, twenty-five dollars ($125.00) a month, which
was given her by a special Act, is now scarcely more than sufficient
to pay her rent, without any allowance for food, clothing and the
other demands of civilized existence. So you will see how undesirable
it would be to distract the public's attention by the mention of
others who happened to contribute a little here and there, but whose
names are not worthy to be mentioned along side of that of Walter
Reed.

With much appreciation of your interest in
this matter, I am
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, J. R. Kean, Colonel, Med. Corps, USA.
